intro: Rhynchopsidium pedunculatum, commonly known as the slender false mallow, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and showy flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and thrives in sunny environments. Its flowers are usually pink or purple, with five petals and a distinctive central column. Rhynchopsidium pedunculatum is often found in grasslands and along roadsides, where it contributes to local biodiversity.
